summary:
The Security Council,

Adopted resolution 2168 (2014) on 30 July 2014, 

Welcoming the Secretary-General's report on UNFICYP, 
Noting the need to maintain UNFICYP beyond 31 July 2014 due to prevailing conditions,
Noting the Secretary-General's intention to report on his good offices, 
Reaffirming the primary role of the UN in assisting parties to reach a comprehensive settlement,

Welcoming resumption of negotiations and the 11 February 2014 Joint Declaration, 
Supporting ongoing efforts to reach a settlement, 
Recalling the importance of full, flexible, and constructive engagement in negotiations, 
Encouraging intensification of substantive negotiations on core issues,

Noting the need for military confidence-building measures, 
Calling for implementation of remaining measures and new steps to build trust, 
Reaffirming the importance of Green Line crossings, 

Urging the two sides to foster positive public rhetoric and explain settlement benefits, 
Highlighting the international community's supporting role,

Taking note of the stable security situation, 
Urging all sides to avoid actions increasing tension or undermining progress, 

Recalling the 1989 aide-memoire, 
Noting with regret the withholding of access to minefields, 
Urging rapid agreement on demining operations,

Commending the Committee on Missing Persons, 
Highlighting the importance of intensifying its activities, 

Agreeing on the essential role of civil society groups, 
Welcoming efforts to promote bicommunal contacts,

Stressing the need for a rigorous approach to peacekeeping deployments, 
Welcoming the Secretary-General's intention to review peacekeeping operations.
Here is a concise summary of the Security Council document:

The Security Council:

Acknowledges progress in negotiations between Cyprus parties, but notes insufficient progress towards a comprehensive settlement.

1. Urges parties to continue discussions on core issues.

2. Takes note of the Secretary-General's report.

3. Calls on leaders to:
    (a) work on core issues;
    (b) work with Technical Committees;
    (c) improve public atmosphere; and
    (d) increase civil society participation.

4. Urges confidence-building measures.

5. Welcomes efforts on missing persons.

6. Reaffirms relevant resolutions.

7. Extends UNFICYP's mandate until 31 January 2015.

8. Calls on parties to engage with UNFICYP on buffer zone demarcation.

9. Calls on Turkish Cypriot side and forces to restore Strovilia's military status quo.

10. Calls on parties to facilitate demining.

11. Requests a report on resolution implementation by 10 January 2015.

12. Welcomes efforts on zero-tolerance policy on sexual exploitation.

13. Decides to remain seized of the matter.
